sen.j: 田楽（でんがく）は、日本の伝統芸能。
sen.e: Dengaku is a traditional Japanese performance art.
Dengaku is a traditional Japanese performance art.
Dengaku is a traditional Japanese performance art.

sen.j: 楽と躍りなどから成る。
sen.e: It is a combination of music and dance.
It is a combination of music and dance.
It is a combination of music and dance.

sen.j: 平安時代中期に成立した。
sen.e: It began in the middle of the Heian Period.
It began in the middle of the Heian Period.
It began in the middle of the Heian Period.

sen.j: 「田植えの前に豊作を祈る「田遊び」から発達した」「渡来のものである」などの説があり、その由来には未解明の部分が多い。
sen.e: Various theories as to its origins include that it developed from a 'ta-asobi' ritual to pray for a good harvest before planting rice, or that it was introduced from overseas and there are still many uncertainties as to its origins.

There are various theories about its origins, including that it developed from a 'ta-asobi' ritual to pray for a good harvest before planting rice or that it was introduced from overseas, but there are still many uncertainties as to its origins.

There are various theories about its origins, including that it developed from a 'ta-asobi' ritual to pray for a good harvest before planting rice or that it was introduced from overseas, but there are still many uncertainties as to its origins.

sen.j: 1096年には、京都の人々が田楽に熱狂することがあり、天皇にも貴族たちがその様をみせた。
sen.e: In 1096 people in Kyoto became enthusiastic about Dengaku and the aristocracy arranged performances for the Emperor.
In 1096, people in Kyoto became enthusiastic about Dengaku and the aristocracy arranged performances for the Emperor.
In 1096, people in Kyoto became enthusiastic about Dengaku and the aristocracy arranged performances for the Emperor.

sen.j: 永長の大田楽という（大江匡房「洛陽田楽記」）。
sen.e: This is referred to as the 1096 Dai-dengaku (in 'Rakuyo Dengaku Ki' (record of Rakuyo Dengaku) authored by Oe-no-Masafusa).
This is referred to as the 1096 Dai-dengaku (in the 'Rakuyo Dengaku Ki' (Record of Rakuyo Dengaku) authored by Oe-no-Masafusa).
This is referred to as the 1096 Dai-dengaku (in the 'Rakuyo Dengaku Ki' (Record of Rakuyo Dengaku) authored by OE no Masafusa).
sen.cmt: Oe-no-Masafusa→OE no Masafusa「永長の大田楽」は「the 1096 Dai-dengaku」と訳しました。

sen.j: 平安後期には寺社の保護のもとに座を形成していった。
sen.e: In the latter stage of the Heian Period Dengaku troupes were formed under the preserve of temples and shrines.
In the latter stage of the Heian Period Dengaku troupes were formed under the protection of temples and shrines.
In the latter stage of the Heian Period Dengaku troupes were formed under the protection of temples and shrines.

sen.j: 田楽を専門に躍るものを田楽法師と言う。
sen.e: Priests who specialized in dancing Dengaku were called Dengaku Boshi (Dengaku Priest).
Priests who specialized in dancing Dengaku were called Dengaku Boshi (Dengaku Priest).
Priests who specialized in dancing Dengaku were called Dengaku Hoshi (Dengaku Priest).

sen.j: 猿楽よりも人気を得ていた時代もあった。
sen.e: There was also a period when Dengaku was more popular than Sarugaku (a Japanese dance).
There was also a period when Dengaku was more popular than Sarugaku, another Japanese dance.
There was also a period when Dengaku was more popular than Sarugaku, another Japanese dance.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府の執権北条高時は田楽に耽溺したことが「太平記」に書かれており、室町幕府の将軍足利義持は増阿弥の芸を好んだ。
sen.e: It is written in the 'Taiheiki'(ancient Japanese literature) that Hojo Takatoki, a regent in the Kamakura shogunate, was addicted to Dengaku and the Shogun Yoshimochi Ashikaga in the Muromachi Shogunate liked the performances of a dancer named Zoami.

It is written in the 'Taiheiki' (ancient Japanese literature) that Hojo Takatoki, a regent in the Kamakura shogunate, was addicted to Dengaku and the Shogun Yoshimochi Ashikaga in the Muromachi Shogunate liked the performances of a dancer named Zoami.

It is written in the 'Taiheiki' (The Record of the Great Peace) that Takatoki HOJO, a regent in the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), was addicted to Dengaku and the Shogun Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA in the Muromachi bakufu liked the performances of a dancer named Zoami.
sen.cmt: Hojo Takatoki→Takatoki HOJOshogunate→bakufu Ashikaga→ASHIKAGA太平記の定訳

sen.j: 大和猿楽の興隆と共に衰えていった。
sen.e: Popularity of Dengaku declined as Yamato Sarugaku (Japanese dance) boomed.
The popularity of Dengaku declined as Yamato Sarugaku (Japanese dance) boomed.
The popularity of Dengaku declined as Yamato Sarugaku (Japanese dance) boomed.

sen.j: 郷土芸能
sen.e: Local Performances
Local Performances
Local Performances

sen.j: 現在までには、びんざさらを使う躍り系の田楽と、擦りささらを使う田はやし系の田楽とに分かれてきた。
sen.e: Up until the present day, Dengaku dances have become divided into those that use Bin-zasara (a type of percussion instrument) and Suri-sasara (a type of percussion instrument).
sen.cmt: やし系の田楽とに分かれてきた ? （抜けました）
sen.e: By the present day, Dengaku dances have become divided into Bin-zasara and Suri-sasara, depending on the type of percussion instrument used.
By the present day, Dengaku dances have become divided into Bin-zasara and Suri-sasara, depending on the type of percussion instrument used.

sen.j: 躍り系の田楽には、豊穣を祈念するものと、魔事退散を祈念するものとがある。
sen.e: Among Dengaku dances, there are those that are prayers for a good harvest and those that are prayers for driving away evil.
Dengaku dances include dances that are prayers for a good harvest, and dances that are prayers for driving away evil.
Dengaku dances include dances that are prayers for a good harvest, and dances that are prayers for driving away evil.

sen.j: 王子神社の田楽・、白鬚神社の田楽、御宝殿の稚児田楽・風流、小滝のチョウクライロ舞、大日堂舞楽などには稚児が演じる躍り系の田楽がある。
sen.e: There are Dengaku dances featuring child dancers including the Oji Shrine Dengaku dance, Shiramine Shrine Dengaku dance, Gohoden's Children's Dengaku, Kotaki Chokuriro Dance, Tainichido Dance and more.

There are Dengaku dances featuring child dancers, including the Oji Shrine Dengaku dance, Shiramine Shrine Dengaku dance, Gohoden's Children's Dengaku, Kotaki Chokuriro Dance, Tainichido Dance and more.

There are Dengaku dances featuring child dancers, including the Oji-jinja Shrine Dengaku dance, Shirahige-jinja Shrine Dengaku dance, Gohoden's Children's Dengaku/Furyu, Kotaki Chokurairo Dance, Dainichi-do Dance and more.
sen.cmt: Chokurio→ChokurairoTainichido→Dainichi-do「風流」追記「白鬚神社」訂正「王子神社」jinja 追記

sen.j: 2006年現在、以下の24件が民俗芸能の田楽の分類で、重要無形民俗文化財に指定されている（指定日 都道府県）。

As of 2006, the following 24 performances are designated important intangible assets in the classification of Dengaku Folk Performances (Date of designation, Prefecture).

sen.j: 食べ物

sen.j: 料理の田楽については、味噌田楽を参照のこと。
sen.e: Regarding Dengaku in cooking, refer to Miso Dengaku.
For information about Dengaku in cooking, refer to Miso Dengaku.
For information about Dengaku in cooking, refer to Miso Dengaku.

sen.j: 田楽の芸に高足というものがあり、竹馬に乗るようなものだったので、これに由来する。
sen.e: Dengaku performances also sometimes include a 'taka-ashi' or single stilt which is stood on like stilts and it is thought to be the origin of the name of the dish 'miso dengaku.'

Dengaku performances also sometimes include 'taka-ashi' or short stilts, and this is thought to be the origin of the name of the dish 'miso dengaku', or tofu with miso is grilled on short skewers that look like small stilts.

Dengaku performances also sometimes include 'taka-ashi' or short stilts, and this is thought to be the origin of the name of the dish 'miso dengaku', or tofu with miso is grilled on short skewers that look like small stilts.

sen.j: 「福山田楽」という、お餅にきな粉をまぶした和菓子も存在する。
sen.e: There is also a Japanese sweet called Fukuyama Dengaku which is a rice cake with powdered soybeans.
There is also a Japanese sweet called Fukuyama Dengaku which is a rice cake with powdered soybeans.
There is also a Japanese sweet called Fukuyama Dengaku which is a rice cake with powdered soybeans.

sen.j: おでんは煮込み田楽より派生した料理である。
sen.e: Oden is a dish derived from boiled Dengaku (originally a grilled tofu dish).
sen.cmt: 煮込み田楽 (originally a grilled tofu dish)
